messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] samurai code of honour
messages.msgSnippet: Andrea/Francisco, Although Nitobe s book was considered very important to the burgeoning field of Japanese studies when it appeared early in the last century,
messages.messageBody:
Andrea/Francisco,

Although Nitobe's book was considered very important to the burgeoning field
of Japanese studies when it appeared early in the last century, it has been
superseded by MANY outstanding works in English. In fact, as G. Cameron
Hurst pointed out in his article ("Death, Honor, and Loyalty: The Bushido
Ideal"._Philosophy East & West_, 40:4 (October 1990), 511-527), Nitobe knew
little about the concept of bushido. Before reading Nitobe's book,
definitely check out Prof. Hurst's comments.

If you do not have access to the journal, the article is reprinted at the
following URL:

http://ejmas.com/jalt/jaltart_hurst_0501.htm

Cheers,

Shannon

messages.subject: Your welcome
messages.msgSnippet: Hey ya ll, no probem! Here s some more stuff for you to check out if you re interested: BUDOSHOSHINSHU: The Warrior s Primer of Daidoji Yuzan Translated by
messages.messageBody:
Hey ya'll, no probem! Here's some more stuff for you to check out if you're interested:
BUDOSHOSHINSHU: The Warrior's Primer of Daidoji Yuzan
Translated by William Scott Wilson (Ohara Publications)
CODE OF THE SAMURAI: A MODERN TRANSLATION OF THE BUSHIDO SHOSHINSHU OF TAIRA SHIGESUKE
Translated by Thomas Cleary (Tuttle Publishing)
And thanks for the history lessons everyone has been dropping on here...I've learned alot about samurai history these past few months, and it's really helped in a few of my history classes.
Phil




---------------------------------

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] samurai code of honour
messages.msgSnippet: That s easy, the correct name for the code of honor for the samurai is Bushido. I have been reading up on the Japanese culture, it s very simple to look up. If
messages.messageBody:
That's easy, the correct name for the code of honor
for the samurai is Bushido. I have been reading up on
the Japanese culture, it's very simple to look up. If
I were you, I would go the book store and try to find
a history book on the Japanese History.
